words.meaning: A way in which something is usually done; a large meeting or conference.
examples: It is a social convention to say 'please' and 'thank you'.
The annual teachers' convention will be held in July.

words.meaning: Based on or in accordance with what is generally done or believed.
examples: She opted for a conventional wedding dress.
His views on politics are very conventional.

words.meaning: (Of lines) to tend to meet at a point; to come from different directions and meet.
examples: The two roads converge at the main square.
Fans from all over the country will converge on the stadium.

words.meaning: Familiar with or knowledgeable about something.
examples: She is conversant with the works of Shakespeare.
You need to be conversant with the latest software to get this job.

words.meaning: Introducing a statement or idea which reverses one that has just been made or referred to.
examples: He is very good at sports; conversely, his academic performance is poor.
You can add the spices now, or, conversely, you can wait until the end.

words.meaning: The process of changing or causing something to change from one form to another.
examples: The conversion of the old warehouse into luxury apartments was a success.
His conversion to a new religion was a surprise to his family.

words.meaning: Having an outline or surface curved like the exterior of a circle or sphere.
examples: The back of a spoon is convex.
A convex lens makes objects appear larger.

words.meaning: A firmly held belief or opinion; a formal declaration that someone is guilty of a criminal offense.
examples: She spoke with great conviction about her political beliefs.
He has a long record of previous convictions for theft.

words.meaning: (Of an atmosphere or event) friendly, lively, and enjoyable.
examples: The dinner party had a convivial atmosphere.
He was a convivial host who made everyone feel welcome.

words.meaning: To call together or summon (an assembly or meeting).
examples: The president decided to convoke a meeting of the advisory board.
Parliament was convoked to address the national crisis.

words.meaning: (Especially of an argument, story, or sentence) extremely complex and difficult to follow.
examples: The movie had a convoluted plot that was hard to understand.
He gave a convoluted explanation that only confused us further.

words.meaning: To deal effectively with something difficult.
examples: She is struggling to cope with the demands of her new job.
He found it hard to cope with his grief after his wife's death.

words.meaning: Abundant in supply or quantity.
examples: She took copious notes during the lecture.
The garden produced a copious harvest of vegetables.

words.meaning: A woman who flirts.
examples: She was known as a coquette in her youth, charming all the young men.
With a playful smile, the coquette teased her admirer.

words.meaning: Warm and friendly.
examples: We received a cordial welcome from our hosts.
Despite their disagreements, they maintained a cordial relationship.

words.meaning: To prevent access to or from an area or building by surrounding it with police or soldiers.
examples: The police cordoned off the street after the accident.
A security cordon was placed around the embassy.

words.meaning: An abundant supply of good things of a specified kind.
examples: The festival was a cornucopia of music, food, and art.
The book is a cornucopia of useful information.

words.meaning: A proposition that follows from (and is often appended to) one already proved; a direct or natural consequence or result.
examples: A necessary corollary of his argument is that we must change our strategy.
Increased unemployment is a corollary of the economic recession.

words.meaning: Relating to the human body.
examples: Corporal punishment is no longer allowed in schools.
The prisoner was subjected to corporal punishment.

words.meaning: Relating to a person's body, especially as opposed to their spirit; having a body.
examples: He was more interested in spiritual matters than corporeal pleasures.
Ghosts are not corporeal beings.

words.meaning: (Of a person) fat.
examples: The corpulent man had difficulty climbing the stairs.
He grew more corpulent as he aged.

words.meaning: To have a mutual relationship or connection, in which one thing affects or depends on another.
examples: Researchers are trying to correlate the two sets of data.
It is well known that smoking correlates with a higher risk of lung cancer.

words.meaning: To confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding).
examples: The witness was able to corroborate the victim's story.
Further research is needed to corroborate the results of the study.

words.meaning: The process of corroding or being corroded.
examples: The corrosion of the old pipes caused a water leak.
Salt and water can accelerate the corrosion of metal.

words.meaning: The science of the origin and development of the universe.
examples: Cosmology seeks to answer fundamental questions about the universe.
The Big Bang theory is a central concept in modern cosmology.

words.meaning: Familiar with and at ease in many different countries and cultures.
examples: New York is a vibrant, cosmopolitan city.
He is a cosmopolitan traveler who has visited over 50 countries.

words.meaning: To care for and protect in an overindulgent way.
examples: She tended to cosset her youngest child.
The hotel cossets its guests with luxurious amenities.

words.meaning: Cared for and protected in an overindulgent way.
examples: He lived a cosseted life, never having to worry about money.
The cosseted celebrity was shielded from the realities of everyday life.

words.meaning: A small group of people with shared interests or tastes, especially one that is exclusive of other people.
examples: A coterie of artists and writers would meet at the cafe.
She was part of a close-knit coterie of friends.

words.meaning: Having the same boundaries or extent in space, time, or meaning.
examples: The city's limits are coterminous with the county's boundaries.
For him, happiness was coterminous with wealth.

words.meaning: To admit as acceptable or possible; to tolerate or approve.
examples: The school will not countenance any form of cheating.
He would not countenance any criticism of his beloved daughter.

words.meaning: Contrary to intuition or to common-sense expectation.
examples: It may seem counterintuitive, but sometimes you have to spend money to make money.
The results of the experiment were completely counterintuitive.

words.meaning: To revoke (an order).
examples: The general decided to countermand his previous order to attack.
The decision to close the factory was countermanded at the last minute.

words.meaning: An argument, idea, or theme used to create a contrast with the main element.
examples: The author uses the character's optimism as a counterpoint to the novel's bleak setting.
The sharp, modern furniture served as a counterpoint to the old building's historic architecture.

words.meaning: Having the opposite of the desired effect.
examples: Micromanaging your employees can be counterproductive.
His aggressive tactics proved counterproductive, as they alienated his supporters.

words.meaning: A sudden, violent, and illegal seizure of power from a government.
examples: The military staged a coup and took control of the country.
Getting the contract was a major coup for the small company.

words.meaning: A final blow or shot given to kill a wounded person or animal.
examples: The final arrow was the coup de grace for the wounded stag.
The company's bankruptcy was the coup de grace to the local economy.

words.meaning: Not openly acknowledged or displayed; secret.
examples: The spy was involved in a covert operation.
They made a covert plan to escape.

words.meaning: To yearn to possess or have (something).
examples: He began to covet his neighbor's luxurious car.
She coveted the lead role in the play.

words.meaning: Having or showing a great desire to possess something belonging to someone else.
examples: He cast a covetous glance at her diamond necklace.
The covetous king wanted to seize all the land for himself.

words.meaning: To intimidate (someone) with threats.
examples: The bully tried to cow the smaller children into giving him their lunch money.
She refused to be cowed by his angry words.

words.meaning: Past tense of cow; caused (someone) to submit to one's wishes by intimidation.
examples: The dog was cowed by its owner's harsh commands.
The employees were cowed into silence by the fear of losing their jobs.

words.meaning: To crouch down in fear.
examples: The small dog would cower in the corner during thunderstorms.
He cowered under the table, hoping the intruder wouldn't see him.

words.meaning: (Especially of a woman) making a pretense of shyness or modesty which is intended to be alluring.
examples: She gave him a coy smile from across the room.
He was being coy about his new girlfriend, refusing to share any details.

words.meaning: Skill in carrying out one's work; an activity involving skill in making things by hand.
examples: The carpenter was a master of his craft.
The local market sells traditional arts and crafts.

words.meaning: Clever at achieving one's aims by indirect or deceitful methods.
examples: The crafty fox managed to steal the chickens.
She had a crafty plan to get what she wanted.

words.meaning: To feel a powerful desire for (something).
examples: After a long day, she began to crave a hot bath.
He craved recognition for his hard work.

words.meaning: Contemptibly lacking in courage; cowardly.
examples: The craven soldier deserted his post in the face of danger.
It was a craven act to run away from the problem.

words.meaning: A line or ridge produced on paper or cloth by folding, pressing, or crushing it.
examples: He carefully folded the letter, making a sharp crease.
She ironed the shirt to remove the creases.

words.meaning: Belief in or acceptance of something as true.
examples: The strange story was given credence by the discovery of new evidence.
I don't give any credence to such wild rumors.

words.meaning: The quality of being trusted and believed in.
examples: The witness's credibility was damaged by his inconsistent testimony.
The newspaper has a reputation for credibility and accuracy.

words.meaning: Able to be believed; convincing.
examples: The police received a credible threat against the embassy.
He was a credible witness who provided a detailed account of the event.

words.meaning: Deserving public acknowledgment and praise but not necessarily outstanding or successful.
examples: She made a creditable effort to finish the race despite her injury.
The team's performance was creditable, even though they lost.

words.meaning: A statement of the beliefs or aims which guide someone's actions.
examples: His credo was to live and let live.
The company's credo is 'the customer is always right'.

words.meaning: A tendency to be too ready to believe that something is real or true.
examples: The con artist took advantage of the old man's credulity.
His credulity was his downfall, as he believed every lie he was told.

words.meaning: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things.
examples: The credulous child believed the story about the monster under the bed.
Credulous people are often the victims of scams.

words.meaning: Of, resembling, or relating to twilight.
examples: Bats are crepuscular animals, active at dawn and dusk.
The crepuscular light of evening cast long shadows.

words.meaning: The loudest point reached in a gradually increasing sound; a gradual increase in loudness.
examples: The music built to a deafening crescendo.
The public anger reached a crescendo and led to protests.

words.meaning: Sad and disappointed.
examples: He was crestfallen when he learned he didn't get the job.
The team was crestfallen after their defeat in the championship game.

words.meaning: A principle or standard by which something may be judged or decided.
examples: The main criterion for the job is a degree in engineering.
What is the criterion for success in this field?
